awd_titl_txt: A Social Network Analysis of Poverty and Health Care Utilization
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this study is to characterize the networks and their effects on health-related decisions and behaviors of medically complex individuals who are high utilizers of health services and who have multiple medical, cognitive, or social challenges. Sociological research has documented the importance of social networks for individual health. Social ties may be even more critical for the health of the most vulnerable. Developing a better understanding of the nature and influence of social networks among the underserved will provide insight into social and health disparities, and how the healthcare and social service systems can better partner with network members to improve the health of disadvantaged individuals. The overall goal of this project is to advance scientific knowledge that will strengthen the formal and informal safety net and improve the well-being of individuals in society.

This project will use egocentric social network analysis and qualitative interviews with patients and providers to examine how disadvantaged individuals' networks are shaped by their social and health conditions, and what kinds of formal and informal social interactions facilitate productive engagement with institutions that promote wellbeing. Specifically, network data will be collected from 100 participants and interviews will be conducted with 50 participants to (1) identify the social network characteristics and complex, interacting social and medical vulnerabilities of individuals in the healthcare safety net; (2) examine longitudinal relationships among social network dynamics, health behaviors, services utilization, and chronic disease management to identify social mechanisms that foster or undermine patients' engagement with healthcare institutions; and (3) assess the strengths, functions, and structural positions of formal and informal caregivers to understand the co-evolving roles of institutions and lay persons in patients' networks. Potential contributions of this study include: (a) transforming our conceptual understanding of the formal and informal safety net among the marginalized and the resources provided by social ties, (b) enhancing our research methods for ascertaining and studying personal social networks in these populations, and (c) amplifying our ability to supplement social networks and leverage them to achieve individual and societal benefits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SAN FRANCISCO, THE

por.por_cntn:
Extensive sociological work has examined social networks' influence on the health of more advantaged groups, and on economic outcomes among disadvantaged populations. In contrast, there is a critical need to learn more about the nature of social networks and their impacts on morbidity and mortality among our most vulnerable citizens. In this mixed methods study, we characterized the social networks of those who use the healthcare safety net, how they change, when and how healthcare providers are involved in them, and how they impact individuals' health.

This research advances our understanding of the social networks of patients experiencing social marginalization and multiple chronic illnesses, and in particular, the kinds of support provided by informal social ties as well as formal ties, or healthcare professionals. Our participants, having high support needs and facing economic precarity, engage in multiple strategies to activate and engage their social network members in supportive activities. Overall, patients? social networks may be larger than expected, but also not as robust as might be ideal given their high needs and economic precarity. In contrast to some of the literature which has found the networks of urban poor to be thinly resourced and fragmented, the networks of our participants offer them sources of instrumental, emotional, and informational support, but may also include higher numbers of ties who are not family, friends, or neighbors per se but who are ?accidental? connections who nonetheless provide important support. Our findings indicate the strong role of providers in participants? networks, comprising approximately half a participants? social network on average, where they significantly lessen the burden and work patients must do to navigate the complexities of the healthcare and social service safety net systems. At times, the kinds and scale of the support they provide to patients is highly unusual (e.g., including financial support) and the strength of the tie and scale of support offered are outsized compared to those documented in the literature.

Our study also contributes to research methods for studying social networks in populations experiencing social marginalization. We expanded the ways in which we ask about social ties, yielding new understandings of the importance of social groups (not just individuals), people who may not be close or well known to our participants but are nearby and accessible to provide support, and a wide range of healthcare providers. These findings emphasize the significance of ascertaining everyday routines and housing situations in order to uncover deeper information about the kinds of social connections people have and the ways in which they depend on them for resources and support.

Finally, this project contributes to our thinking about how social institutions and services can supplement and mobilize networks to help support marginalized individuals. We find that healthcare or social services providers are embedded in the core parts of patients? social networks; additionally, we found that the support providers give helps to repair individuals? trust in social institutions and integration into health and social service programs. However, providers are deeply concerned about the sustainability and scalability of the programs of which they are a part, which put them in a position to become a crucial part of patients? social networks, but in ways that may require longer-term and deeper relational work than programmatic intent or resources allow for. Given the inefficiencies and inadequacies in our social and healthcare safety net, the kinds of programs that we studies are critical for mitigating social determinants of disease and improving the wellbeing of marginalized groups. This is especially evident during the COVID pandemic, where our ongoing data collection indicated that both patients and providers found the transition to telehealth to be extremely challenging. Patients? multiple, complicated health conditions required constant monitoring of symptoms and fine-tuning of treatment, that were difficult to manage remotely, especially without the benefit of physical exams. Patients reported a multitude of other challenges accessing critical healthcare and social services. These findings reveal both interesting instances of resilience but also important areas of added tenuousness and exacerbated precarity in individuals? connections to their social networks and to the social institutions on which their health and wellbeing depend.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Janet K Shim
